Surviving Without Google Reader

25 Jun 2013

RSS is dead, long live RSS

According to Google, I am a dying statistic.

â€œusage of Google Reader has declinedâ€

My daily routine for the past four or five years has involved checking-in with Google Reader every morning and every evening to catch up on sites that I either donâ€™t visit (ex. Daring Fireball), or donâ€™t frequent enough to keep up with their onslaught of posts (ex. The Verge). To me, RSS is one of the, if not the, best Internet technologies invented. It gives me the freedom to procure my own â€œtop listâ€ of sites and read them like an Internet-newspaper digest whenever I please. So imagine my dismay when I see:

If you havenâ€™t heard, Google Reader will be â€œSunsettedâ€ on July 1st. To Googleâ€™s credit I was able to take away a copy of my OPML subscriptions list, but as I discovered, thereâ€™s few places to go.

Google simultaneously saved and killed the RSS reader market

Initially, I looked at services like Googleâ€™s Currents, and Flipboard; and hated them. My issue with these services is I may as well just be using the content providers websites, as Google Reader has solidly bred me into the camp where I just want a list of headlines from every source ordered chronologically which I can J and K through. I also tried Feedly and signed up for Diggâ€™s Reader, but Feedly left me feeling overwhelmed with features I didnâ€™t understand and werenâ€™t documented, and Digg still havenâ€™t rolled out their Reader due to what looks like issues with the service.

There are services like Sean Inmanâ€™s Fever and Tiny Tiny RSS, but both are self-hosted and my current webspace provider doesnâ€™t allow me to use all the features they require, though running one of them on a RaspberryPi may prove an interesting summer project.

Giving up

Sadly, I did concede in the end and couldnâ€™t persevere to find a good solution. I uninstalled the Google Reader app from my phone and removed it from the default tabs on Chrome. My information glut has begun.

My only viable alternative for now has been to install Hacker News and Reddit apps, which I try to keep on top of at least 2-3 times a day, but sadly, much like it used to pre-Reader, news and information can just pass me by. (Luckily the big stuff like all the current Snowden malarky stays on the frontpages for long enough for me to pick up on.)

Asideâ€“or â€œWhereâ€™s my feed.xml file?â€

On the topic of RSS but slightly aside from the main point; yes I am lacking an RSS feed for this site. Rest assured Iâ€™m hacking away at a solution and should be committing it to the Git repo Soonâ„¢.

20 Jun 2013

About Jekyll

20 Jun 2013

Jekyll is a simple, blog-aware, static site generator. It takes a template directory containing raw text files in various formats, runs it through Markdown (or Textile) and Liquid converters, and spits out a complete, ready-to-publish static website suitable for serving with your favorite web server. Jekyll also happens to be the engine behind GitHub Pages, which means you can use Jekyll to host your projectâ€™s page, blog, or website from GitHubâ€™s servers for free.
